column6: List of material topics
column7: Climate change, disaster resilience and emergency response, affordability and availability of insurance, and trust and transparency

column6: Management of material topics
column13: Supporting our physical scenario analysis, our annual capital stress testing focused on climate-related physical risks this year. Stress testing is undertaken through the Group's Internal Capital Adequacy Assessment Process (ICAAP) framework. It is a valuable tool for exploring the potential implications of climate risks, which provides input into our risk appetite, capital target setting and contingency planning. Future stress tests are expected to incorporate transition and liability risks.
column21: Climate Risks, Stress Testing, Contingency Planning

column13: Experiences in Customer, Digital & Data, Insurance, Leadership and Risk faculties. Courses provide our people with career pathways, improved capabilities, and new skills to suit the changing workforce.

column6: Management of material topics
column13: Using our ClaimsTracker service, customers can lodge and track their claims digitally. More than 600,000 customers have used this service since its launch in 2022, creating over one million individual interactions. More than 36% of claims are now lodged online.

column6: Infrastructure investments and services supported
column13: We engaged in independent market research to understand levels of preparedness before and after the North Island floods and ex-Tropical Cyclone Gabrielle in early 2023. By sharing our claims analysis and research alongside simple actions people can take, we are supporting our customers in getting prepared.

column6: Infrastructure investments and services supported
column13: We have a more significant impact when we work with our partners to develop programs that help our customers and the community prepare for, respond to, and recover from extreme weather. As an example, included in Figure 3, we featured the refreshed Get Prepared app that we co-created through our Australian Red Cross partnership in the NRMA Insurance' First Saturday' winter campaign.

column7: ~132,000 Increase in customer numbers in Direct Insurance Australia in FY23. $10,203m claims were paid (up 20% from $8,488m in FY22).

Operations assessed for risks related to corruption
Communication and training about anti-corruption policies and procedures
column13: Our Code of Ethics & Conduct (Code) sets out the behaviours expected of everyone at IAG. The Code provides our people with principles and a framework to make informed business decisions.

column6: Communication and training about anti-corruption policies and procedures
column13: The Group Anti-Bribery and Corruption Policy (ABC Policy) supports IAG's purpose and strategy by prohibiting bribery and corruption, providing precise requirements for managing bribery and corruption risks, and compliance with relevant laws and regulations. All material breaches are reported to the Board by the Group's Chief Risk Officer.

column6: Communication and training about anti-corruption policies and procedures
column13: The Group Conflicts of Interest Policy sets out IAG's approach and requirements for managing conflicts of interest across the Group. It is designed to (i) ensure everyone understands how to identify conflicts of interest and what is expected of them when a conflict of interest arises and (ii) promote fairness and honesty.

column6: Confirmed incidents of corruption and actions taken
Legal actions for anti-competitive behavior, anti-trust, and monopoly practices
Approach to tax
column13: The strategy is implemented through IAG's Tax Governance Framework, which is approved by the Board and supported by governance processes and controls that ensure it is implemented with continued effectiveness. Based on this, effective policies and processes are in place to manage tax risk.
column21: Tax Governance Framework, Board Approval, Governance Processes

column6: Tax governance, control, and risk management
column7: The Company and its Australian resident wholly-owned subsidiaries adopted the tax consolidation legislation on 1 July 2002 and are therefore taxed as a single entity from that date. The Company is the head entity within the tax-consolidated group. Tax-consolidated groups are recognised as amounts receivable/(payable) from/(to) other entities in the tax-consolidated group in conjunction with any tax funding arrangement amounts. IAG recognises any difference between these amounts as an equity contribution or distribution.

column6: Stakeholder engagement and management of concerns related to tax
column7: Audit Committee (BAC) Assists the Board by overseeing the integrity of IAG's external statutory financial reporting for the Group, tax and economic risks, the provision of high-quality financial and audit-related non-financial information that can be relied on by the Board to make informed judgements and the independence of the External Auditor, Internal Auditor, and Chief Actuary.

column6: Country-by-country reporting
column7: The difference between the effective tax rate and the Australian corporate rate of 30% is due to the non-deductible items, primarily the $40 million ASIC civil penalty for infringements of the Australian Securities and Investments Commission Act 2001 (Cth) and capital note payments. The effective tax rate is also higher than in previous years due to the lower contribution from New Zealand, which has a 28% tax rate.
